Description: Grey-brown pottery pilgrim-flask with circular body, short neck and two handles. On side (a), within a narrow sunken border, Saint Menas stands to front, his arms outstretched in blessing. Above each arm is a cross. He has curly hair, wears a short tunic and a long cloak, and is flanked by camels. On side (b), set at an angle to the vertical, is a large wreath with small circles at the top and bottom, surrounding a cross. Mould-made, one side joined to the other slightly twisted; the mouth is damaged and the whole is very worn.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased from the Earl of Belmore. Late Roman, about AD 480-650. Comparanda: Sides (a) and (b): very close: Kiss 1989a: no. 21, from Kom el-Dikka, Alexandria, context of AD 560-610. Side (a): close to: Ede n.d.a: 159, lot 29, dated sixth to seventh century AD; Habib n.d.: [11], dated sixth to seventh century AD. Near: Empereur 1998b: 629, fig. 30, from a tomb at Gabbari, Alexandria; Kiss 1989a: no. 17, from Kom el-Dikka, Alexandria, context of AD 560-610. Side (b): near: Kaufmann 1908: 70, fig. 50, a mould from Abu Mena; Kiss 1989a: no. 38, from Kom el-Dikka, Alexandria, context of AD 600-620. Bibliog: Nesbit 1873: 330; probably Belmore 1843: pl. 3:103.
